content.title: Keeping Your Leopard Gecko Hydrated
content.content: Despite coming from arid habitats, leopard geckos require consistent access to fresh water and high-humidity refuges for healthy shedding. This guide covers water provision, humid hide setup, and recognizing hydration issues.
Leopard geckos obtain water from three sources: drinking directly from water dish, licking moisture droplets, and from prey items. A properly maintained water dish is essential year-round.

content.text: Water Dish Specifications:

items: Size: 3-5 inches diameter, shallow depth (1-2 inches tall) - gecko should be able to drink without climbing inside
Material: Ceramic or glass preferred (heavy, stable, non-porous). Avoid plastic (tips easily, harbors bacteria in scratches)
Shape: Low-sided bowl or ramp-style dish - gecko should access water easily without struggle
Weight: Heavy enough that gecko cannot tip or flip (empty weight 8+ oz recommended)
Color: Earth tones or solid colors (not bright colors that may stress gecko)

content.text: Water Dish Placement:

items: Location: Cool end of enclosure (warm end evaporates water too quickly, increases ambient humidity excessively)
Stability: Place on level substrate or directly on enclosure floor if substrate very loose
Accessibility: Ensure gecko can reach from all hides without crossing entirely exposed areas
Distance from Heat: At least 12 inches away from basking spot to prevent rapid evaporation

rows: Geckos can drown in deep dishes if exhausted or flipped upside-down; low sides = easy access
Zoo Med Repti Rock Water Dish (small), Fluker's Food/Water Dish
Cannot be tipped by gecko; stable during feeding activity nearby
Exo Terra Water Dish, Generic ceramic pet bowls (3-4" diameter)
No sharp edges or rough texture that could injure gecko's face
Gecko's entire head fits comfortably without squeezing into narrow space

content.content: Water Availability is Critical: Fresh water must be available 24/7/365. Leopard geckos drink primarily at night when active. Empty water dish even for a few hours can cause dehydration, especially during shedding.

content.text: Daily Water Maintenance:

items: Empty, rinse, and refill water dish every 24 hours (more frequently if contaminated with substrate or feces)
Use dechlorinated water - let tap water sit 24 hours OR use water conditioner (Seachem Prime, API Stress Coat)
Check water level - gecko may drink significant amount overnight, especially after eating or during shed
Remove any debris immediately (substrate, shed skin, feces, dead feeder insects)
Wipe dish interior with damp cloth if biofilm visible (slimy coating)

content.text: Weekly Deep Cleaning:

items: Scrub dish with reptile-safe disinfectant (F10SC diluted OR 10:1 water:vinegar solution)
Use soft brush to remove mineral deposits and biofilm completely
Rinse thoroughly with clean water (3-4 rinses minimum) - no soap residue
Air dry completely OR dry with clean paper towel before refilling
Replace dish if cracked, chipped, or excessively scratched (bacteria harboring in damage)

content.text: Water Source Options:

items: Tap Water (Treated): Most common. Let sit 24hrs to off-gas chlorine OR add dechlorinator (1-2 drops per cup). Avoid if tap water has high chloramine levels
Filtered Water: Brita or similar pitcher filters remove chlorine, taste, and some minerals. Generally safe for reptiles
Bottled Spring Water: Safe and convenient. Avoid distilled water (lacks minerals) or mineral water (too many dissolved solids)
RO/DI Water: Reverse osmosis or deionized water acceptable but may need mineral supplement for long-term use
AVOID: Well water with high iron/sulfur, water with high fluoride (>2 ppm), softened water (high sodium)

content.content: Biofilm Formation: Slimy coating on water dish interior is bacterial biofilm. While not immediately toxic, biofilm reduces water quality and can harbor pathogens. Clean dish thoroughly at first sign of biofilm (usually 3-5 days if unchanged).

The humid hide is a critical component of leopard gecko care. It provides a high-humidity microclimate (70-80%) within the otherwise arid enclosure (30-40% ambient), enabling healthy shedding without raising overall humidity to problematic levels.

content.text: Humid Hide Requirements:

items: Enclosed Design: Must have solid top/sides to trap moisture. Single entrance or two entrances acceptable. NO open-top hides (humidity escapes immediately)
Snug Fit: Interior just large enough for gecko to fit comfortably. Tight spaces = better humidity retention + security feeling
Opaque Material: Non-transparent walls increase gecko security. Cork bark, ceramic, plastic, or resin all work
Moisture Substrate Inside: Line interior with sphagnum moss (best), damp paper towels, or coconut fiber to hold moisture

content.text: Humid Hide Placement:

items: Location: Middle of enclosure OR slightly toward cool end. NEVER under basking lamp (heat dries out moss rapidly)
Temperature Inside: Ideally 80-85F (warm enough for comfort but cool enough to retain moisture)
Accessibility: Gecko should be able to move between humid hide and other hides without excessive open space exposure

content.text: Sphagnum Moss Preparation:

items: Use dried sphagnum moss (NOT peat moss - too acidic) - available at reptile stores or garden centers
Soak moss in dechlorinated water for 5-10 minutes until fully saturated
Squeeze out excess water firmly - moss should clump when squeezed but NOT drip water
Fluff slightly and fill humid hide to depth of 1-2 inches (enough to hold moisture, not so deep gecko struggles to use hide)
Moisture level check: Press moss with finger - should feel damp/springy, not soggy or dry

rows: 3-5 sprays of dechlorinated water into hide, avoid soaking gecko directly
Look inside hide - moss should appear damp and dark colored (dry moss is light tan/brown)
Prevents moss from drying out between mistings
Remove stuck shed pieces with fingers or tweezers - shed skin holds moisture and creates bacterial growth
Prevents mold and maintains moss effectiveness
Discard old moss, clean hide with disinfectant, rinse thoroughly, add fresh moss
Prevents mold/bacterial buildup even if not visible
Scrub with F10SC or 10:1 water:white vinegar, rinse 3-4 times, air dry
Eliminates accumulated bacteria and prevents mold

content.content: Mold Risk in Humid Hide: If you see fuzzy white, green, or black growth on moss, replace moss immediately and disinfect hide. Mold spores can cause respiratory issues. Prevention: Replace moss monthly, avoid over-misting (moss should NOT be dripping wet).

Humid Hide Purpose: Arid species like leopard geckos shed in burrows or under rocks where humidity naturally accumulates. The humid hide replicates this natural moisture refuge, allowing gecko to shed properly without requiring high ambient humidity (which causes respiratory problems).
Leopard geckos shed their skin every 4-8 weeks depending on age and growth rate. Juveniles shed more frequently than adults. Proper hydration and humid hide access are critical for complete sheds.

content.text: Normal Shedding Timeline:

items: Days 1-2 (Pre-Shed): Gecko colors dull/fade, appears whitish or grayish overall. May refuse food (normal). Increase time in humid hide
Day 3 (Shed Day): Skin loosens and gecko rubs against surfaces to start shed. Often completes shed within 30-60 minutes
During Shed: Gecko peels skin off in pieces and typically eats it (recycles nutrients - normal behavior)
After Shed: Colors bright and vibrant again. Check for stuck shed on toes, tail tip, eyelids, and vent
Hatchlings: Shed every 2-3 weeks (rapid growth). Adults: Every 4-8 weeks

content.text: Supporting Healthy Sheds:

items: Ensure humid hide is properly maintained (70-80% humidity inside, moss damp)
Mist humid hide more frequently during pre-shed (daily vs. every 2-3 days)
Do NOT handle gecko during shed - skin is delicate and handling causes stress
Provide rough surfaces (rock, cork bark) for gecko to rub against to remove shed
Offer hydrating feeders during pre-shed: hornworms, silkworms (high moisture content)
Temper expectations - healthy geckos typically shed completely without assistance

content.content: Stuck shed (retained skin after shedding) indicates insufficient humidity or dehydration. Common problem areas: toes, tail tip, eyelids, and vent. Untreated stuck shed can cut off circulation to toes/tail or cause eye infections.

content.text: High-Risk Areas for Stuck Shed:

items: Toes: Shed rings constrict around digits, cutting off circulation. If untreated, toe dies and falls off (permanent disfigurement)
Tail Tip: Shed cap accumulates at tail tip. Multiple layers cause tip to die and drop off (tail tip necrosis)
Eyelids: Thin shed over eyes prevents full eye closure, causes irritation, increases infection risk
Vent Area: Thick shed around vent (cloaca) prevents defecation - serious if untreated

content.content: Toe/Tail Necrosis Risk: Stuck shed constricts blood flow. If shed ring remains on toe for 7+ days, tissue death (necrosis) is likely. Toe will darken, dry out, and fall off. CHECK TOES after every shed - this is the #1 cause of gecko disfigurement.

content.text: Removing Stuck Shed Safely:

items: Step 1 - Humid Soak: Place gecko in shallow plastic container with damp paper towels (NOT water - drowning risk). Cover container with breathable lid (poke air holes). Let sit 15-20 minutes
Step 2 - Gentle Removal: After soaking, use damp Q-tip to GENTLY roll shed away from skin. Do NOT pull forcefully - if shed does not come off easily, repeat soak
Step 3 - Toe Check: Inspect each toe individually. Use magnifying glass if needed. Gently roll shed rings off each toe with damp Q-tip
Step 4 - Repeat if Needed: If stuck shed remains, repeat soak 12 hours later. Do NOT force shed removal - causes skin damage
Eyelid Shed: Do NOT attempt removal yourself - gecko will remove naturally within 24-48hrs. If persists 3+ days, vet visit required (risk of corneal damage)

content.text: Preventing Stuck Shed:

items: Maintain humid hide properly: 70-80% humidity inside, moss kept damp, mist every 2-3 days
Increase misting frequency to daily during pre-shed (when gecko colors dull)
Verify ambient humidity 30-40% (not too low, not too high)
Ensure gecko has access to humid hide at all times (not blocked by décor or other gecko if cohabitating)
Provide adequate hydration: fresh water available 24/7, offer hydrating feeders like hornworms
Check for underlying health issues if stuck shed occurs repeatedly - dehydration, parasites, kidney disease all affect shedding

content.content: Dehydration in leopard geckos can be subtle initially but becomes life-threatening if untreated. Early recognition and intervention prevent serious health complications.

rows: Eyes appear recessed into head; eye area looks hollow or wrinkled
Increase misting of humid hide to daily; verify water dish full; offer hornworms (high moisture); vet visit if persists 48hrs
Skin does not snap back quickly when gently pinched (skin turgor test); excess skin folds visible
Check water availability, increase humid hide moisture, soak gecko 15min in damp container, vet visit if no improvement in 24-48hrs
Inside of mouth appears tacky/sticky instead of moist; saliva thick
Ensure fresh water available, mist humid hide, offer juicy feeders (hornworms, silkworms), monitor closely
Gecko less active than usual, struggles to move, doesn't respond to stimuli
Emergency - vet visit required same day for fluid therapy (subcutaneous fluids)
Stuck shed on toes/tail after multiple shed cycles despite humid hide
Re-evaluate hydration setup: humid hide moisture level, water availability, ambient humidity; fecal exam for parasites (cause malabsorption)
Not defecating for 10+ days, dry/hard urates (white part should be soft), dark concentrated urates
Increase hydration immediately, provide humid hide access, offer high-moisture feeders, vet check if no defecation 14+ days
Visible hip bones, thin tail (fat stores depleted), spine prominent
Emergency vet visit - likely requires assisted feeding or fluid therapy; dehydration combined with malnutrition

content.content: Dehydration Emergency: If gecko shows sunken eyes + lethargy + unresponsive behavior, this is CRITICAL dehydration. Do NOT attempt home treatment - seek emergency vet care immediately. Gecko may require subcutaneous fluids and hospitalization.

content.text: Home Rehydration for Mild Cases:

items: Increase humid hide misting to daily (ensure 70-80% humidity inside)
Offer high-moisture feeders: hornworms (85% water), silkworms (83% water)
Provide 15-minute damp towel soak daily for 3-5 days (place gecko in shallow container with damp paper towels, cover with breathable lid)
Verify water dish is full, clean, and accessible 24/7
Monitor for improvement: eyes should appear less sunken, skin turgor improves, gecko more active
If NO improvement within 48 hours OR gecko worsens, vet visit required

content.content: Prevention is Key: Dehydration is almost entirely preventable with proper husbandry. Fresh water available 24/7 + properly maintained humid hide + 30-40% ambient humidity = well-hydrated gecko. Monitor these three factors daily.

content.text: Summer (High Heat, Low Humidity):

items: Water evaporates faster - check dish twice daily, refill as needed
Humid hide dries out quickly - may need daily misting instead of every 2-3 days
Increase hydrating feeder frequency (hornworms, silkworms 2x per week)
Consider second water dish if first dries out rapidly
Monitor ambient humidity - should not drop below 25% even in summer (use room humidifier if necessary)

content.text: Winter (Dry Indoor Air from Heating):

items: Central heating reduces indoor humidity significantly - ambient may drop to 15-20%
Increase humid hide misting frequency - may need every other day instead of every 3 days
Use room humidifier set to 35-40% to stabilize ambient humidity (not directed at enclosure - affects overall room)
Geckos may drink more during winter - ensure water dish refilled promptly
Stuck shed more common in winter due to dry air - vigilant post-shed checks essential

content.text: Brumation Period (Winter Cooling):

items: Geckos undergoing brumation (natural winter slowdown) drink less frequently but STILL need water available
Do NOT remove water dish during brumation - gecko may drink occasionally
Humid hide still required even if gecko inactive (in case shed occurs during brumation)
Check water dish weekly during brumation - refill as needed (evaporation still occurs)
